title: Creates the New York autism spectrum disorders treatment, training and research council and provides for the powers and duties of the council
summary: Creates the New York autistic spectrum disorders treatment, training and research council and provides for the powers and duties of the council.

                                 I N  A S S E M B L Y

                                      ___________

       Introduced  by  M.  of A. WEISENBERG, MAISEL, BENEDETTO, MILLMAN, TITUS,
         JAFFEE, SCHIMEL, CASTRO, SCHROEDER, SPANO, TITONE  --  Multi-Sponsored
         by  -- M. of A. ABBATE, AUBRY, BARCLAY, BURLING, CONTE, CROUCH, DESTI-
         TO, DUPREY, FINCH, GABRYSZAK, GIBSON, HOOPER, JORDAN, LIFTON, LUPARDO,
         MARKEY, MAYERSOHN,  McENENY,  McKEVITT,  MOLINARO,  PHEFFER,  RABBITT,
         RAIA, SAYWARD, SCARBOROUGH, SWEENEY, THIELE, TOBACCO, TOWNS, ZEBROWSKI
         -- read once and referred to the Committee on Health

       AN  ACT to amend the executive law, in relation to creating the New York
         autism spectrum disorders treatment, training and research council and
         providing for the powers and duties of the council

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  Intent.  The  legislature  hereby finds and declares that
    2  autism spectrum disorders, hereinafter ASDs, currently  affect  approxi-
    3  mately  one  in  110 children and are considered to be an "urgent public
    4  health concern" by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
    5    The legislature further finds that New York state  has  not  responded
    6  sufficiently  to  this  crisis.  In  its 2010 report, the New York state
    7  Interagency Task Force on Autism,  hereinafter  Task  Force,  identified
    8  five  primary  needs  of  the  growing  population  of New York citizens
    9  affected by ASDs: coordination of state services, early  identification,
   10  lifelong  service  delivery, increased dissemination of information, and
   11  coordination of research efforts. First, as a collaborative effort of 11
   12  independent state agencies that each serve individuals impacted by ASDs,
   13  the Task Force itself exemplifies the need for coordination of research,
   14  treatment and training responsibilities. Second, while  the  Task  Force
   15  determined  that  early  identification and intervention were crucial to
   16  minimizing the symptoms and impact of ASDs, it reported that only  eight
   17  percent  of pediatricians routinely screen for ASDs and approximately 30
   18  percent of children with ASDs do  not  receive  the  early  intervention
   19  services  provided  by  the  New York State Department of Health. Third,

                                                                  LBD01579-01-1

       A. 2954                             2

    1  recognizing that the thousands of children diagnosed with ASDs will soon
    2  age out of the state's educational system, the Task Force noted a dearth
    3  of post-secondary training and transitional services. Fourth,  the  Task
    4  Force  determined  that  individuals and families affected by ASDs would
    5  benefit from a centralized clearinghouse of  relevant  information,  and
    6  called  for  the  provision of user-friendly access to such information.
    7  Finally, the Task Force reported that  collaboratively  determining  the
    8  direction of future ASD research would best utilize available public and
    9  private funding.
   10    The  legislature  therefore  declares  that  there is a need to expand
   11  treatment, training and research with regard to ASDs  --  including  the
   12  enhancement of efforts to improve access to, and the efficacy of, needed
   13  services, support and treatment.
   14    S  2.  This  act  shall  be  known, and may be cited, as the "New York
   15  autism spectrum disorders treatment, training and research act".
   16    S 3. The executive law is amended by adding a new article 41-A to read
   17  as follows:
   18                                ARTICLE 41-A
   19                     NEW YORK AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS
   20                  TREATMENT, TRAINING AND RESEARCH COUNCIL
   21  SECTION 908. DEFINITIONS.
   22          908-A. NEW YORK AUTISM SPECTRUM  DISORDERS  TREATMENT,  TRAINING
   23                   AND RESEARCH COUNCIL; PURPOSE AND ORGANIZATION.
   24          908-B. FUNCTIONS, POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE COUNCIL.
   25    S 908. DEFINITIONS. WHEN USED IN THIS ARTICLE:
   26    1.  "AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER" OR "ASD" MEANS A NEUROBIOLOGICAL CONDI-
   27  TION THAT INCLUDES AUTISM, ASPERGER SYNDROME, RETT'S SYNDROME, OR PERVA-
   28  SIVE DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDER;
   29    2. "FAMILY" MEANS THE PARENT OR LEGAL GUARDIAN OF AN INDIVIDUAL  DIAG-
   30  NOSED WITH AN AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER; AND
   31    3.  "PATIENT"  MEANS  AN  INDIVIDUAL DIAGNOSED WITH AN AUTISM SPECTRUM
   32  DISORDER.
   33    S 908-A. NEW YORK AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS  TREATMENT,  TRAINING  AND
   34  RESEARCH COUNCIL; PURPOSE AND ORGANIZATION. 1. THERE SHALL BE WITHIN THE
   35  EXECUTIVE  DEPARTMENT  THE NEW YORK AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS TREATMENT,
   36  TRAINING AND RESEARCH COUNCIL, HEREINAFTER COUNCIL, WHOSE PURPOSES SHALL
   37  BE TO:
   38    (A) DEVELOP A COORDINATED NEW YORK  STATE  AUTISM  SPECTRUM  DISORDERS
   39  TREATMENT,  TRAINING  AND  RESEARCH  POLICY  AND PLAN, HEREINAFTER STATE
   40  POLICY AND PLAN, WITH RESPECT TO THE PROVISION OF SERVICES  TO  PATIENTS
   41  AND THEIR FAMILIES;
   42    (B)  REVIEW  STATE  AGENCY  INITIATIVES FOR THEIR CONSISTENCY WITH THE
   43  STATE POLICY AND PLAN;
   44    (C) PROVIDE A CONTINUING FORUM FOR DISCUSSION RELATED TO THE  DEVELOP-
   45  MENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STATE POLICY AND PLAN; AND
   46    (D)  TAKE  THE STEPS ENUMERATED HEREIN TO EXPAND AND COORDINATE TREAT-
   47  MENT, TRAINING AND RESEARCH.
   48    2. THE COUNCIL SHALL BE COMPRISED OF TWENTY-EIGHT MEMBERS AS FOLLOWS:
   49    (A) THE COMMISSIONER OF THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, THE COMMISSIONER  OF
   50  THE  DEPARTMENT OF LABOR, THE COMMISSIONER OF THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND
   51  FAMILY SERVICES, THE COMMISSIONER OF EDUCATION, THE COMMISSIONER OF  THE
   52  OFFICE  OF MENTAL HEALTH, THE COMMISSIONER OF THE OFFICE FOR PEOPLE WITH
   53  DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, THE COMMISSIONER OF THE OFFICE OF  TEMPORARY
   54  AND  DISABILITY  ASSISTANCE, THE SUPERINTENDENT OF THE INSURANCE DEPART-
   55  MENT, THE CHANCELLOR OF THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE CHANCELLOR
   56  OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE CHAIR OF THE COUNCIL ON CHILDREN

       A. 2954                             3

    1  AND FAMILIES, THE CHAIR OF THE COMMISSION ON QUALITY OF CARE AND ADVOCA-
    2  CY FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES, AND  THE  EXECUTIVE  DIRECTOR  OF  THE
    3  DISABILITIES  PLANNING  COUNCIL,  ALL OF WHOM SHALL SERVE EX OFFICIO AND
    4  WHO MAY DESIGNATE REPRESENTATIVES TO ACT ON THEIR BEHALF;
    5    (B)  SEVEN MEMBERS APPOINTED BY THE GOVERNOR, WHO SHALL POSSESS EXPER-
    6  TISE IN ASDS. AT LEAST TWO  APPOINTEES  SHALL  REPRESENT  NOT-FOR-PROFIT
    7  ENTITIES  WITH  THE  PRIMARY  PURPOSE  OF PROVIDING ACCESS TO EDUCATION,
    8  INFORMATION AND/OR SERVICES RELATED TO THE CARE OF PATIENTS; AND
    9    (C) EIGHT MEMBERS APPOINTED BY THE GOVERNOR ON THE  RECOMMENDATION  OF
   10  THE LEGISLATIVE LEADERS AS FOLLOWS:
   11    (1)  THE  TEMPORARY  PRESIDENT  OF  THE  SENATE AND THE SPEAKER OF THE
   12  ASSEMBLY SHALL EACH RECOMMEND THREE MEMBERS TO THE COUNCIL.  THE  TEMPO-
   13  RARY  PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE AND THE SPEAKER OF THE ASSEMBLY SHALL EACH
   14  RECOMMEND AT LEAST ONE CLINICAL OR RESEARCH EXPERT IN THE FIELD OF  ASDS
   15  AND AT LEAST ONE FAMILY MEMBER OF A PATIENT; AND
   16    (2)  THE  MINORITY LEADER OF THE SENATE AND THE MINORITY LEADER OF THE
   17  ASSEMBLY SHALL EACH RECOMMEND ONE MEMBER TO THE COUNCIL.
   18    3. VACANCIES IN THE MEMBERSHIP OF THE COUNCIL SHALL BE FILLED  IN  THE
   19  MANNER PROVIDED FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   20    4.  THE  COMMISSIONER OF THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND THE COMMISSIONER
   21  OF THE OFFICE FOR PEOPLE WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES SHALL SERVE, EX
   22  OFFICIO, AS CO-CHAIRS OF THE COUNCIL. ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES OF THE COUN-
   23  CIL SHALL BE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF, AND EXECUTED BY, THE  DEPARTMENT  OF
   24  HEALTH  AND THE OFFICE FOR PEOPLE WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES PURSU-
   25  ANT TO AN AGREEMENT EFFECTED BY THE CO-CHAIRS.
   26    5. MEMBERS OF THE COUNCIL SHALL  RECEIVE  NO  COMPENSATION  FOR  THEIR
   27  SERVICES BUT SHALL BE REIMBURSED FOR NECESSARY EXPENSES.
   28    6.  THE  COUNCIL SHALL MEET QUARTERLY, OR MORE FREQUENTLY IF ITS BUSI-
   29  NESS SHALL REQUIRE, PROVIDED THAT THE COMMUNITY FORUMS REQUIRED PURSUANT
   30  TO SECTION NINE HUNDRED EIGHT-B  OF  THIS  ARTICLE  SHALL  CONSTITUTE  A
   31  FORMAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL.
   32    S  908-B.  FUNCTIONS,  POWERS  AND DUTIES OF THE COUNCIL. 1. NOT LATER
   33  THAN ONE YEAR AFTER THE EFFECTIVE DATE  OF  THIS  ARTICLE,  THE  COUNCIL
   34  SHALL  CONDUCT  COMMUNITY  FORUMS  TO  GAIN  INPUT FROM PATIENTS, FAMILY
   35  MEMBERS, SERVICE PROVIDERS,  EXPERT  RESEARCHERS  AND  OTHER  INTERESTED
   36  PARTIES CONCERNING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE STATE POLICY AND PLAN REQUIRED
   37  BY  THIS  SECTION. THE COUNCIL SHALL THEN CONDUCT COMMUNITY FORUMS EVERY
   38  FIVE YEARS, OR MORE FREQUENTLY AS THE COUNCIL SHALL DETERMINE. COMMUNITY
   39  FORUMS SHALL BE CONDUCTED IN OR AROUND ALBANY, BINGHAMTON, BUFFALO, LONG
   40  ISLAND, NEW YORK CITY,  NORTHERN  METROPOLITAN  NEW  YORK,  PLATTSBURGH,
   41  POTSDAM, POUGHKEEPSIE, ROCHESTER, SYRACUSE, AND OTHER AREAS AS THE COUN-
   42  CIL SHALL DETERMINE.
   43    2.  THE  COUNCIL  SHALL PROVIDE THE INITIAL REPORT OF THE STATE POLICY
   44  AND PLAN REQUIRED BY THIS SECTION TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE ON
   45  OR BEFORE FEBRUARY FIRST, TWO THOUSAND  TWELVE,  AND  SHALL  PROVIDE  AN
   46  UPDATE OF SUCH POLICY AND PLAN BY FEBRUARY FIRST OF EVERY YEAR THEREAFT-
   47  ER.  THE  STATE POLICY AND PLAN SHALL INCLUDE COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION,
   48  FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS CONCERNING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE FOLLOW-
   49  ING:
   50    (A) COORDINATION OF SERVICES, INCLUDING: COORDINATING  STATE  SERVICES
   51  AND  PROVIDING  CASE MANAGEMENT; CLARIFYING AND STREAMLINING ELIGIBILITY
   52  AND INTAKE PROCESSES FOR STATE SERVICE SYSTEMS; ADDRESSING THE NEEDS  OF
   53  PATIENTS  WHO  FAIL  TO MEET ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA OF STATE AGENCIES; AND
   54  UNITING PUBLIC AND PRIVATE AGENCIES IN A MANNER  THAT  WILL  BEST  SERVE
   55  PATIENTS  AND  THEIR  FAMILIES.  IN  ASSESSING THE STRENGTHS AND GAPS IN

       A. 2954                             4

    1  SERVICES FOR PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES,  THE  STATE  POLICY  AND  PLAN
    2  SHALL INCLUDE EVALUATIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS BY REGION;
    3    (B)  EARLY  IDENTIFICATION  AND INTERVENTION, INCLUDING: STANDARDIZING
    4  ASD SCREENING PRACTICES; TRAINING EDUCATORS, MEDICAL  PROFESSIONALS  AND
    5  OTHER SERVICE PROVIDERS TO RECOGNIZE AND TREAT ASDS; AND PROMOTING EARLY
    6  CHILDHOOD SCREENING BY PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS;
    7    (C)   LIFELONG   SERVICE  DELIVERY,  INCLUDING:  PROMOTING  ACCESS  TO
    8  EVIDENCE-BASED SERVICES FOR PATIENTS OF ALL AGES; ESTABLISHING TREATMENT
    9  GUIDELINES AND TRAINING PROGRAMS FOR CAREGIVERS;  PROVIDING  RESIDENTIAL
   10  SUPPORTS  TO  ADULT  PATIENTS;  AND IMPLEMENTING EMPLOYMENT TRAINING AND
   11  POST-SCHOOL TRANSITIONAL SERVICES;
   12    (D) FAMILY SUPPORT, INCLUDING:  EXPANDING  RESPITE  CARE  OPTIONS  AND
   13  IMPLEMENTING OTHER MEANS TO REDUCE STRAIN ON FAMILIES;
   14    (E)  INCREASED DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION, INCLUDING: INCREASING ASD
   15  AWARENESS PROGRAMS; DISTRIBUTING BEST PRACTICES  TO  EDUCATORS,  MEDICAL
   16  PROFESSIONALS  AND  OTHER SERVICE PROVIDERS; CONTINUING THE TASK FORCE'S
   17  EFFORTS TO CREATE A CENTRALIZED HUB OF INFORMATION ON ASDS  THROUGH  THE
   18  LAUNCH  OF  AN ONLINE INITIATIVE FOR ADULTS AND CHILDREN ON THE SPECTRUM
   19  (NEW YORK ACTS); AND ENHANCING SUPPORT  FOR  PATIENTS  AND  FAMILIES  IN
   20  NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING COMMUNITIES;
   21    (F)  COORDINATED  RESEARCH,  INCLUDING:   UTILIZING AVAILABLE RESEARCH
   22  FUNDS IN THE MOST EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT  MANNER;  TRANSLATING  RESULTS
   23  INTO  IMPROVED  TREATMENT  PRACTICES; DISTRIBUTING RESULTS TO EDUCATORS,
   24  MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS AND  OTHER  SERVICE  PROVIDERS;  AND  UNITING  ASD
   25  RESEARCHERS IN SEEKING TO ACHIEVE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF ASDS;
   26    (G)  FINANCING  TRAINING, TREATMENT AND RESEARCH IN THE STATE, INCLUD-
   27  ING: MAKING FINANCING MORE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE; STRENGTHENING FAMILY
   28  SERVICES AND SUPPORTS; PROVIDING A SEAMLESS SPECTRUM OF  SERVICES  IRRE-
   29  SPECTIVE  OF  AGENCY  JURISDICTION;  IDENTIFYING  EXISTING AND POTENTIAL
   30  SOURCES OF FUNDING; AND PARTNERING WITH PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS, FOUNDATIONS
   31  AND OTHER ENTITIES; AND
   32    (H) A STATISTICAL ANALYSIS OF DATA CONCERNING THE PREVALENCE OF AUTISM
   33  IN NEW YORK STATE, BOTH STATEWIDE AND BY REGION; A LISTING OF  AVAILABLE
   34  AND  PROPOSED  PROGRAMS,  AND THEIR AVAILABILITY BY REGION; A LISTING OF
   35  AVAILABLE AND PROPOSED EXPENDITURES, AND THEIR AVAILABILITY BY REGION; A
   36  LISTING OF FINANCIAL RESOURCES AVAILABLE FOR THE PROVISION  OF  SERVICES
   37  TO  PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES; AND SUCH OTHER INFORMATION AS THE COUN-
   38  CIL SHALL DEEM RELEVANT.
   39    3. EXCEPT WHERE OTHERWISE PROHIBITED BY STATE STATUTE  OR  BY  FEDERAL
   40  LAW,  RULE  OR  REQUIREMENT, THE PLAN SHALL BE BINDING UPON MEMBER STATE
   41  AGENCIES, WHICH SHALL PROMULGATE REGULATIONS AND TAKE SUCH OTHER ACTIONS
   42  REQUIRED TO EFFECTUATE THE STATE POLICY AND PLAN.
   43    4. THE COUNCIL SHALL SELECT AND DESIGNATE REGIONAL NEW YORK CENTERS ON
   44  AUTISM AND RELATED DISABILITIES, HEREINAFTER NYCARD FACILITIES, FOR  THE
   45  PURPOSE  OF IDENTIFYING, DISSEMINATING, AND ASSISTING IN THE IMPLEMENTA-
   46  TION OF EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES TO SERVE PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES.
   47    (A) THE COUNCIL SHALL ESTABLISH CRITERIA FOR THE SELECTION AND  DESIG-
   48  NATION OF NYCARD FACILITIES, WHICH SHALL INCLUDE AN ASSESSMENT OF APPLI-
   49  CANT FACILITIES':
   50    (1) PARTICIPATION IN TRAINING TEACHERS, PARENTS AND PROFESSIONALS;
   51    (2) LEVEL OF NON-STATE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AVAILABLE TO SUPPORT OPER-
   52  ATIONS;
   53    (3)  UNDERSTANDING  OF PROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARTICULATED BY THE
   54  COUNCIL;
   55    (4) PROPOSED GEOGRAPHICAL AREA TO BE SERVED;
   56    (5) PROPOSED WORK PLAN AND STAFF EXPERTISE;

       A. 2954                             5

    1    (6) RELATIONSHIP WITH ENTITIES OR COMMUNITIES TO BE SERVED,  EVIDENCED
    2  BY  SUCH  FACTORS  AS  REPRESENTATION ON BOARDS OF DIRECTORS OR ADVISORY
    3  COMMITTEES; AND
    4    (7) SUCH OTHER FACTORS AS THE COUNCIL SHALL DETERMINE.
    5    (B)  THE  COUNCIL SHALL DEVELOP A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS, A REQUEST FOR
    6  QUALIFICATIONS, OR A REQUEST FOR EXPRESSIONS OF  INTEREST  AS  IT  DEEMS
    7  APPROPRIATE;  AND  IT  SHALL  ACCEPT APPLICATIONS IN RESPONSE FOR DESIG-
    8  NATION AS A NYCARD FACILITY FROM NOT-FOR-PROFIT, ACADEMIC  AND  RESEARCH
    9  ENTITIES  IN  THE STATE. WITHIN EIGHTEEN MONTHS AFTER THE EFFECTIVE DATE
   10  OF THIS ARTICLE THE COUNCIL SHALL:
   11    (1) DESIGNATE AS NYCARD FACILITIES: FEDERAL STUDIES TO ADVANCE  AUTISM
   12  RESEARCH  AND  TREATMENT  (STAART)  NETWORK  PROGRAMS LOCATED WITHIN THE
   13  STATE, THE CODY CENTER FOR  AUTISM  AND  DEVELOPMENTAL  DISABILITIES  AT
   14  STONY  BROOK UNIVERSITY, AND THE CENTER FOR AUTISM AND RELATED DISABILI-
   15  TIES AT THE UNIVERSITY AT ALBANY;
   16    (2) EXPAND CURRENT NYCARD FACILITIES  LOCATED  IN  OR  AROUND  ALBANY,
   17  BUFFALO,  NEW  YORK  CITY, NORTHERN METROPOLITAN NEW YORK AND ROCHESTER;
   18  AND
   19    (3) CREATE ONE OR MORE NYCARD  FACILITIES  IN  OR  AROUND  BINGHAMTON,
   20  PLATTSBURGH, POTSDAM, POUGHKEEPSIE, SYRACUSE AND SUCH OTHER AREAS AS THE
   21  COUNCIL SHALL DETERMINE.
   22    (C) NYCARD FACILITIES SHALL PROVIDE TRAINING, REFERRAL AND INFORMATION
   23  FOR  PARENTS, EDUCATORS, MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS AND OTHER SERVICE PROVID-
   24  ERS, INCLUDING;
   25    (1) INFORMATION AND REFERRAL;
   26    (2) EDUCATION AND TRAINING;
   27    (3) TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND CONSULTATION;
   28    (4) PROVISION OF, OR REFERRAL TO, FAMILY SUPPORT GROUPS;
   29    (5) DISSEMINATION OF EVIDENCE-BASED MODELS OF PRACTICE  FOR  EFFECTIVE
   30  SERVICE DELIVERY; AND
   31    (6) SUCH OTHER SERVICES AS THE COUNCIL SHALL REQUIRE.
   32    (D)   WHERE   FEASIBLE,   NYCARD   FACILITIES   SHALL   ALSO   PROVIDE
   33  TREATMENT-BASED SERVICES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO,  CASE  CONSULTA-
   34  TION AND CLINICAL SERVICES.
   35    (E)  THE  COUNCIL  IS  HEREBY AUTHORIZED TO CONTRACT FOR SERVICES WITH
   36  DESIGNATED NYCARD FACILITIES PURSUANT TO THIS SUBDIVISION AND TO PROVIDE
   37  GRANTS PURSUANT TO SUCH CONTRACTS WITHIN AMOUNTS DESIGNATED SPECIFICALLY
   38  THEREFORE. THE COUNCIL MAY ACT THROUGH ONE OR MORE  MEMBER  STATE  AGEN-
   39  CIES,  WHICH  IT SHALL DESIGNATE BY MAJORITY VOTE, FOR ADMINISTRATION OF
   40  SUCH CONTRACTS AND GRANTS. INSOFAR AS POSSIBLE, WHERE PROVISION OF  SUCH
   41  SERVICES  IS  PAID  FOR,  IN WHOLE OR IN PART, THROUGH A CONTRACT WITH A
   42  STATE AGENCY, THE COST CHARGED TO RECIPIENTS SHALL BE REDUCED PRO  RATA.
   43  CONTRACTS WITH NYCARD FACILITIES SHALL VARY DEPENDING ON THE SERVICES TO
   44  BE  PROVIDED,  AND ANY SUCH CONTRACT SHALL REQUIRE THAT FUNDING PROVIDED
   45  BY, THROUGH OR PURSUANT TO THIS  SUBDIVISION,  NOT  BE  USED  TO  OFFSET
   46  EXISTING EXPENDITURES FOR THE SAME OR SIMILAR PROGRAMS.
   47    5.  NYCARD  FACILITIES,  AS WELL AS ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVING FEDERAL OR
   48  NON-STATE GRANT FUNDS FOR RESEARCH, MAY RECEIVE GRANTS PURSUANT TO  THIS
   49  SUBDIVISION  FOR  RESEARCH WITHIN AMOUNTS DESIGNATED SPECIFICALLY THERE-
   50  FORE.  THE COUNCIL IS HEREBY AUTHORIZED TO ADMINISTER  SUCH  GRANTS  AND
   51  MAY  ACT THROUGH ONE OR MORE MEMBER STATE AGENCIES WHICH IT SHALL DESIG-
   52  NATE BY MAJORITY VOTE.  SUCH GRANTS MAY ALLOW  FOR  THE  ENHANCEMENT  OF
   53  ACTIVITIES  FUNDED  FROM  SUCH  NON-STATE SOURCES THAT ARE ALREADY BEING
   54  UNDERTAKEN BY SUCH ORGANIZATIONS, INCLUDING: THE CONTINUATION OF ONGOING
   55  RESEARCH; THE PROVISION OF TECHNICAL INFORMATION; GUIDANCE  FOR  PRACTI-
   56  TIONERS  ON    ASD  CARE  STRATEGIES,  THERAPIES,  MEDICATIONS AND OTHER

       A. 2954                             6

    1  RELATED  MATTERS;  COLLABORATIONS    WITH  PRACTITIONERS,  SCHOOLS   AND
    2  NETWORKS;  AND  OTHER  ACTIVITIES  THE  COUNCIL  DEEMS APPROPRIATE. SUCH
    3  GRANTS MAY BE USED FOR ANY PURPOSE IN  FURTHERANCE  OF  SUCH  ACTIVITIES
    4  INCLUDING,  WITHOUT  LIMITATION, THE PURCHASE OF EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES,
    5  PAYMENT OF SALARIES, OR OTHER ACTIVITIES AND PURPOSES AS APPROVED BY THE
    6  COUNCIL.
    7    S 4. This act shall take effect immediately.
actClause: AN ACT to amend the executive law, in relation to creating the New York autism spectrum disorders treatment, training and research council and providing for the powers and duties of the council
